commentBody: I absolutely love the ends of a loaf of bread. There's nothing better for ripping into chunks and dropping in your soup, or chili.
Wonderful to see Will Shortz's name again as editor of the puzzle. Hope he's been restored to a full measure of good health.

I found this one tougher than the average Tuesday, with lots of specific knowledge clues that were outside my ken.  I actually used the theme to open up the pesky NE corner (having no clue about Emily OSMENT). Getting ANGELANGLE gave me enough letters to piece it together.  I was struck by the plethora of Qs and Xs.
RE: 11D, Washington feels very attacked!

Went dieting instead of FASTing (29 Down) which just led me down a frustrating detour.

Saw the theme quickly, and I loved it ‚ÄúANGEL ANGLE‚Äù is a cute phrase I hadn‚Äôt encountered before.

Many years ago, when I was still a child, when a fresh oven-warm loaf of bread was broken into halves, there were two particularly favoured pieces. The first slice off the outie end and the two crust ends, or heels. The latter particularly cut at least half an inch thick and liberally spread with butter, or even better real beef dripping, complete with chunks, direct from the Sunday roast.

When I couldn't find the Tupperware, I flipped my lid.

(I should learn to contain myself.)
Best Tuesday puzzle I've seen in a long time. Good fun.

Well done, Aaron.  Lots of thought went into that.  The revealed was necessary towards my final success. 

Thanks for such a masterful Tuesday puzzle.

Seen from any ANGLE, this puzzle was easy/not easy‚ÄîQUITE a TOP TIER RAMBLE.  (DE POT right over USER?) 

And the EXIT?  RE: DONE, I'm sorry that it is.  

Thank you Adam.   Come back soon.
Hard for a Tuesday.
We loved the more modern clues in today‚Äôs puzzle! Has anyone solved the extra ‚Äúbackflip‚Äù clues in the Constructor Notes? üßê

Very enjoyable!

I've always though the combination ADOBE ABODE was kind of cool.  D and B hopping over O.

I'd construct a crossword based on ADOBEABODE, other than that I has no qualifications whatsoever to do so.  None.

I was able to figure out [Most simple looking bedspreads?] but no luck so far with [Barbecue entrees that get cooked the fastest?], at least without crossing entries. Can anyone assist? I'm sure it's just as clever as the other theme entries, so I'm looking to smile just one more time at Adam Aaronson's wit.

For me this took twice as long as a Tuesday puzzle usually does, and longer than most Wednesdays or the occasional Saturday. Lots of names and slang (I came up with CUKE in the end, and I got KNEX from crosses, whatever that is, but those things being next to each other exemplifies my today's troubles). I broke down and looked up the actor in the NE... 

The theme is fun-ish I suppose, but the revealer is a huge stretch for me. I would never call what's going on in the themed entries BACKFLIPS. Having seen the explanation of the revealer in the column I get it, but I still don't like it. Perhaps my problem is that I like to visualize stuff so when I'm reading about BACKFLIPS I see a gymnast in my mind, and what she's doing is nothing like what the themed entries do. I understand the wordplay, but it leaves me cold.

Also, is EPA one of the agencies that will get dissolved by the new "englightened" administration?
A tough Tuesday (for me).
Love when a Friday puzzle comes early!

COVERLET COVERLTE
PLAIN PLANI
QUILT QUITL
THROW THRWO
COVER COVRE
 
I give up, anyone?

CUKE ‚Ä¶ really NYT ???

And please don‚Äôt explain it to me. It‚Äôs not a proper word no matter how many dictionaries the enthusiastic defenders find it in. 

Also as @Andrzej notes CUKE next to KNEX ‚Ä¶.

Otherwise the puzzle was a fine Tuesday. Certainly not a Wednesday. 

J

Add me to the 2X club. Twice as long as a typical Tues. 

Loved every minute. Thanks, Adam Aaronson!
With a couple of interruptions, that took me over 40 minutes. I'm glad tomorrow is Wednesday and I can start using Autocheck again.
Washington also has a (state) disambiguator in Wikipedia.

Definitely a challenging Tuesday, but I was able to beat my average time by a couple of mins. Of course my recent averages have been about 10 mins under my average as I have gotten better.  Overall e enjoyed it, theme and challenge.
Cool theme. The rest was rather ordinary. CUKE? BAMA? 'K off.
CUKE was a stretch but I got there. Great theme, satisfying solve!

Sam, you were not alone in thinking of military rank for 28A‚ÄîI did the same! It was actually my last word to fall because I had a typo in 3D (singular MAILMaN instead of the plural) and I kept trying to figure out what RaDONE had to do with the military‚Ä¶ oops! I didn‚Äôt totally get 42A. I‚Äôve always pronounced EWE as in ‚Äúyou‚Äù but this clue seems to indicate that it is pronounced ‚Äúoo‚Äù without the y sound at the beginning. Is this a dialect/accent thing? I looked up the pronunciation on Google and found the ‚Äúyou‚Äù version of it. The search took me down an interesting linguistics rabbit hole. TIL about the original pronunciation of Ewing, NJ: https://reddit.com/r/linguistics/comments/se57c0/when_did_the_eweyou_merger_happen_in_english/
I enjoyed this more than any other Tuesday I've completed.  Well done.

I'll join the "took longer than usual" crowd, although when I looked at my stats I was just a couple of minutes over my average, so it didn't take as long as I thought it did. A lot of it was waiting for crosses to help with some of the answers that were slow in coming. Eventually, though the answers came and I was able to complete the puzzle.

Solving the theme came early, though, with QUITE QUIET, and the rest of the theme answers weren't difficult to suss out. As someone who grew up in the Erector Set/Tinker Toy era, I did manage to notice that K'NEX (connects) was a next-generation building toy system and appeared to be pretty good for a variety of projects.

Thanks, Adam, may all your train trips be as productive!

So Aaron, this puzzle took you only 8 hours to construct.  I‚Äôd be on that train until the next eclipse before the first draft would be completed! Tough Tuesday! Took a long time to solve, but that‚Äôs fine by me.

This puzzle had the most Qs and Xs I recall seeing. That wasn‚Äôt a bug, but a feature.  

Like others, I got stuck on 29D, ONAFAST. I kept ONAdiet for far too long.  At one point I entered ONAdate, and I was prepared to get my dander up when I realized it was incorrect.

On a similar note, if someone said we were about to see the EXIT- of the -SEXIST (and his cronies), I‚Äôd be doing BACKFLIPS.  Since that‚Äôs just a VAPEPEN dream, I‚Äôm back in my FUNK.

One more thought. *They* have access to the US treasury now üò° but if they gain access to private accounts like VENMO- they would surely experience my (verbal) -VENOM.

As suggested yesterday, *bum* dia.
Can someone explain BAMA? I cannot fathom this entry. Is it because I‚Äôm from the UK or because I haven‚Äôt seen the film?
Neat puzzle.  It was fun being able to use the revealer to help solve the puzzle.  Too often I don't complete the revealer clue until the very end of the puzzle when it's of no use.

I loved the clue for MAILMEN and QUITEQUIET and that‚Äôs about it. 

I passionately hate CUKE. 

Looking forward to Wednesday‚Äôs puzzle.
I'll embrace the EQUINE/EQUINOX just because I like all the Qs.

Like many, I finished well above my average‚Ä¶ in fact I was fairly significantly slower than my Wednesday average. However, I found the puzzle to be appropriate Tuesday difficulty. Even taking into account the ‚Äútrademarked‚Äù name, I was kinda impressed that Adam Aaronson managed to work in 2 Q words that didn‚Äôt have a ‚ÄúU‚Äù. Anyone else immediately think of the movie ‚ÄúThe Sting‚Äù  when they figured out 32A?

Strands Thread.  Harbor no fantasies about posting spoilers until after the View All Replies button please.  


Strands #338
‚ÄúElf-centered‚Äù
üîµüîµüîµüîµ
üü°üîµüîµ


Crestfallen I was that my first entry was not the spanner.  Upper left themer was tricky.

Had a lot of fun with this! Enjoyed the theme, and it's always nice to see a collection of Q's, X's and K's. My Tuesday avergage was destroyed a while ago when I accidentally left a crossword open on my laptop for almost 24hrs, but from recollection this one only took me a couple minutes longer than usual.
However, I don't know if I have ever found an answer I loathe more than CUKE. I have never heard the word before. Is it more common in the states? Especially with the JFK crossing (a bit of a shot-in-the-dark for me), I sat for almost five minutes at the end of my solve trying to see where I'd went wrong, trying to squeeze every four letter vegetable I knew of into the space. It couldn't be CoKE and it couldn't be CaKE.... God knows why CUKE never entered my head ‚Äî maybe I should wait until my coffee has had time to actually start working on me.
Overall I'm willing to forgive the CUKE clue for all of the fun letters in this one. It was a good solve!

TOP TIER Tuesday!  A fun theme and some clever wordplay. 

I like the clues ‚ÄúPuff Piece‚Äù for VAPE PEN and ‚ÄúStart to fall‚Äù for EQUINOX. I also like that ART and MOMA were both clued to Warhol.

I always enjoy reading about what inspired a theme or the seed entry.  I say that because BACKFLIPS reminds me of a silly thing that popped into my mind the other while I was enjoying an apple turnover. I wondered if Gwyneth Paltrow ever said to her sunbathing daughter, ‚ÄúTurnover Apple‚Äù. 

OK, I'll never be a constructor.
Any crossword with the dude abides
I really enjoyed this one. I'm annoyed I didn't get VAPEPEN apart from through crossers. Lots of clues needing a bit of thought but not impossible as they were proper words and not proper names.
Nice Tuesday treat.  Extra points for [Start to fall] for EQUINOX.

Fun puzzle. Pretty smooth solve for the most part, but got stuck for a bit around VENMOVENOM. That just wasn't dawning on me and had to work the crosses for a while before I finally got it. Just made for a nice workout.

Just really liked all the theme answers. 

Kind of fun puzzle find today that I'll put in a reply. 

....

Ten minutes over my average today! Didn‚Äôt know about a NIQAB. Mistakenly thought it was a HIJAB. Totally different thing. Also had no clue who 10D or 18D were. Had ONADIET for 29D. üòû

Maybe I should‚Äôve got my ‚òïÔ∏è first this morning!
I caught on to the theme fairly quickly, so really enjoyed this clever Tuesday puzzle, so definitely looking forward to more from Adam

THE DUDE.
Fantastic way to start the day.

My kids were quoting the Duderino
long before they could watch the movie.

Lotta ins, lotta outs, lotta what-have-yous‚Ä¶

Yeah, well, that's just, like, your opinion, man.

It really tied the room together.

You brought the Pomeranian bowling? 

You‚Äôd be surprised how many times 
they were the perfect response.

The Dude abides. 
Obvs.

Lovely serendipitous BACKSKIP theme echo, as this puzzle uses every letter of the alphabet except Y and Z.




Et tu, emu.
At first, 58A struck me as being whacked out to the nth degree, but it's actually the cleverest of the bunch. Well done.

Really, NYT? Terry Veg?? If we‚Äôre just making up people now, why not throw in John Pork or Calvin Cucumber while you‚Äôre at it? At least they‚Äôd make me laugh. Let‚Äôs try to keep the references to real things next time, shall we?‚Äù
Some clever turns of phrase in the clues for a Tuesday puzzle. My personal favorite: Start to fall?

Crossword Revolution D15: FUNK The George Clinton and Pfunk variety: https://youtube.com/watch?v=gjKFCYzqq-A Stevie Wonder too: https://youtube.com/watch?v=97hwNY3ni10 And Chaka: https://youtube.com/watch?v=cm_cFzVAoo8 A Crosswords Saved the Day production.

Cuke?  

I suppose the word "veggie" in the clue was to tip me off that this was a shortened word, but "for short" or "familiarly" would have worked.  Personally, I just go ahead and say the word "cucumber" however long it takes.

And cucumber has no place on a tray of crudit√©.  Too wet.

I lit up when I saw Aaron‚Äôs name atop the grid, because his puzzles crackle with cleverness, and once again, he delivered.

Sure, hearing the phrase QUITE QUIET and thinking there might be a theme there ‚Äì the genesis of this puzzle, according to Aaron‚Äôs notes ‚Äì that is lovely but standard constructor thinking.  Finding four theme answers, each consisting of a pair of five-letter words, that‚Äôs a step up.  Coming up with BACK FLIP ‚Äì the perfect revealer ‚Äì that‚Äôs top tier.

I don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôve ever marked six clues on a Tuesday as candidates for my Clues of the Week list, as I did today.  Sparkling wordplay clues.  Overall, both the answer set and the cluing are vibrant, humming with energy.

And a junk-free grid of answers, the kind I look at and suddenly go calm and zen.

The solve?  That is, the most important element?  Well, for me, this was fun to untangle, capped by that stand-and-cheer revealer.

A jewel box today, primo quality abounding.  I will light up once again, even brighter, Adam, next time I see your name gracing a grid.  Thank you for a splendid outing!

The plentiful Q's and X's were a bonus, but otherwise this was not a fun puzzle for me. It felt much more like a Wednesday. If Tuesdays become Wednesdays and Wednesdays become Thursdays... are we all weak?

Had to look up "Crimson Tide", and the NE corner was giving a lot of trouble, so I threw in the towel and looked up a few other things. (Should have known MOMA... doh!) 

Your mileage may vary (we Canajians use kilometrage).
A rather VENOMOUS Tuesday. Although it was a clever puzzle it definitely belongs later in the week. Jeez if this is a Tuesday crossword I can hardly wait until Friday or Saturday.
Last week there were complaints about the puzzles getting easier. Based on this one, Friday's should be a bear.

I loved this puzzle. A winner of a theme and fun fill to boot.

Re the constructor's comments: In a saner world that took climate change seriously a train ride from NYC to Rochester would take a lot less than 8 hr. It should be faster than driving. But I guess in this one case the long ride worked out to  our benefit.
This was great. But I felt like I was time travelling into Wednesday. The theme was very Wednesday-ish and this felt a tad tough for Tuesday.

Very nice puzzle! The NE took me a little longer than it should have as I confidently entered NEW YORK for 11D (thinking state and city) even though I was pretty sure the Warhols were at MOMA (maybe they had been moved?) so a facepalm there. Also noticed that a reparsed 49A could serve as a slogan for the MeToo movement. I was surprised that the many Qs and Xs were unintentional - wonder what the record is?

Interesting.  Looks like they are mixing things up again, or it was just an off day for me.  Took 85% longer than average.  The theme dawned on me about 2/3 the way through the solve, and it certainly helped me finish.
Superb Tuesday puzzle. The clues were top-notch.
Outstanding. Most fun puzzle in a while. Loved [start to fall?] and the gobsmacking wordplay.
The most tricky clue by far was for GEORGIA but I guess nobody wants to admit they didn‚Äôt know what disambiguator meant.

Super fun! Lovez et batch.

Is it just me, or do the words ewe, bama, and epee keep popping up over the past few weeks?

NE corner came slowly, but got it from the theme. My real problem was that I oafishly spelled SAKE incorrectly, and who knows KNEX from KNIX? I vaguely remembered a nephew building with something like it.  I could not find the error in my grid for a tediously long time. Off to drown my sorrows in some COFFI üòù
Excellent Wednesday puzzle! Bravo Adam!

That felt late-week hard for me, but perhaps because of unknown names, as well as some American usage that needed a bit of thought to retrieve.
I guessed bEaR for the state animal of Illinois, which didn't help either.
Relished the clever cluing, but eventually needed an annoying lookup to resolve one error. So today I learned that SAKi is sometimes transliterated SAKE, and that KNiX makes underwear, not construction sets.

I needed the revealer to get the theme of this puzzle (and it took a while) but once I got it, what a delight!

So many fun clues, and a tricky theme that impressed me with its word play.

Also wanted to add.... today's mini was all right.  üòâ
Felt a little tough for a tuesday IMO. Was not a fan of CUKE
loved this one!!! was surprised at the amount of unusual letters in this one (q,x,v,j). great theme and likely my favorite one this year so far

The tallest person in the tour group was the one to spot the church steeple.  He also kept sneaking sips of whisky, and the tour guide kept hassling him.  But when he offered to share with the group, all was forgiven.


SPIRE SPIER takes FLASK FLAKS but CURES CURSE.
The clue for 49A should have been "misogynist leaves"

Happy Groundhog Day, everybody!!

Fun theme. 

Surprised that so many here think CUKEs belong on a crud platter.

Nice puzzle.  Good, tricky cluing that raised it to Wednesday difficulty.  That's a good thing, as far as I'm concerned.  More bang for your buck.

I'm happy that OSMENT got clued by Haley Joel's younger sister, but did they have to reference "Hannah Montana" rather than "Young Sheldon" (or its sequel "Georgie and Mandy's First Marriage")?
Is it just me or are the Monday and Tuesday puzzles getting harder? I am find the rest of the week to be easier for me, but M & T have challenges.
Another Wednesday puzzle masquerading as a Tuesday; nice theme however. Slight nitpick:1D covers the entire body, not just the face.

Thank God I am retired and had the time to attempt this Tuesday's puzzle. If it wasn't for Autocheck, I would have never finished it. Am I the only one that found this hard for a Tuesday?
Let's vote!
Tough little Tuesday and a military "decoration" would be a medal/award not a rank. Just sayin'

Clever, fun puzzle. I loved it.
Another thing I love? Joel‚Äôs back doing the mini! I missed him, and thanks to those who filled in.
IMHO, Way too hard for a Tuesday puzzle. Maybe it was just me, but I didn't come close. Most Tuesday puzzles are pretty much a breeze for me.
No discussion about the "heel" of bread loaves?  Or did I miss it.  Is Will back or what?

That was a tough Tuesday. I feel better seeing others here feel the same. Misery loves company and all that.

Burqa before hijab before NIQAB. So many ways to hide a woman‚Äôs face.

An interesting theme that took a while to land (without doing a BACK FLIP). 

I do love HOT SAKE, but not the inevitable hangover that follows.
Nice theme! Good rewarding solve.

Nice Tuesday theme and construction. Saw the theme with QUITEQUIET, so finished this one in my average amount of time for a Tuesday.

Only nit: both "rhythm" and "blues" are verbs, albeit quite uncommon ones.

I used to depend on the NYT XWD to tell me what day it was. Now, I'm not complaining, just lazy. Several times this morning I double-checked that today is Tuesday, not Wednesday. The puzzle was very un-Tuesday for me, but that doesn't mean I didn't enjoy it; it just means it took me longer. 

Once I realized what we were doing (QUITEQUIET) I grinned and got down to business. I don't know that the revealer actually meant anything to me; the clues themselves were good enough. My favorite might have been VENMOVENOM. This was a great puzzle for my crazed mind...yesterday in the ER was a toughie. People were coming out of the woodwork, as though busses had dropped them off. (I'm a volunteer, not a professional) It always seems as though people decide to hold onto their problems until Monday ("Let's not ruin the weekend; my appendix will last until Monday") and then it's a real emergency. 

But today's puzzle was fun, solvable without lookups, and a great way to start my day. Oh, and it's book club day! I'm even wearing my book club socks...piles of books climbing up my shins! Have a great day, friends!

My usual late puzzle find. A Friday form December 12, 1975 by Dennis Listort. Just three grid-spanning entries in that one: WHATDIDDELAWARE WHENDIDMARYLAND IDONTKNOWALASKA Here's the Xword info link: https://xwordinfo.com/PS?date=12/12/1975&g=35&d=A ....
Really nice puzzle.  The fact that the differences between the key word pairs were exact transpositions of the last two letters was really impressive.  Congratulations to the constructor!

Thank you for getting NIQAB right. I lived in the Arabian Gulf for 7 years and I am tired of people using burqa to refer to all the things. Hijab, niqab, abaya, burqa are all distinctly different items. Though it gets a lot of coverage, I have never seen anyone wearing a burqa. And the niqab is indeed the only one of them that fits the clue.
Two minutes (roughly 10%) over my average for a Tuesday, but totally worth it!
An impressive number of 'Q' words. Good puzzle.
Adam -- glad you got something from the Rochester no show eclipse.

I loved this puzzle but i am stumped by the additional clues proposed in the constructor‚Äôs notes and it‚Äôs driving me crazy!

Has anyone figured out the answers to [Most simple looking bedspreads?] or [Barbecue entrees that get cooked the fastest?]

Every time I see a crossword by Adam Aaronson I think of the classic Simpsons gag where Selma is trying to spread the word about Marge being pregnant so she pulls out the phone book and dials the first number, A AARONSON and starts to tell him.  Then there is a fade to show elapsed time and, exhausted, she says, ‚Äú‚Ä¶just thought you‚Äôd like to know, Mr. Zukowski,‚Äù hangs up and says, ‚ÄúThere! Aaronson and Zukowski are the two biggest gossips in town, soon everyone will know!‚Äù

A brilliant bit, much like this puzzle.  And I enjoyed all the extra‚ÄùX‚Äùs sand ‚ÄúQ‚Äùs!
So fun!  Thank you for a nice start to the day!
Isn‚Äôt the point of a puzzle to puzzle?  I never understand the need to complain. Just enjoy!

What a fun puzzle, slightly harder than the average Tues, but right up my alley. And only slower than my Tues average by 11 seconds. I did get lucky with a few guesses. Once I got the theme, it all fell into place nicely.
Red Tide = BAMA?  can someone help me out here.  Love this puzzle.
11D, 'Only U.S. state whose Wikipedia article has a "(U.S. state)" disambiguator'--what about Oklahoma?
I don't get all the CUKE hate. Too, me awhile to come up with it, but that's not unusual for me.... Clever, fun puzzle.

One more late puzzle. Yet another type that I've never encountered before. Anyway - a Sunday from June 15, 1975 by William Lutwiniak with the title "Do-it-yourself." In that one, all the theme answers did not have a clue. In the Xword page it's just a colon ":" for each of them but I don't know whether that was actually in the paper. Anyway - some theme answers: WITHOUTACLUE UNNUMBERED (have to wonder how that one may have appeared in the paper) UNINFORMATIVE MEANINGLESS DRAWINGABLANK ILLDEFINED NOTHINGATALL WIDEOPENSPACES WITHOUTMEANING Here's the Xword Info link: https://xwordinfo.com/PS?date=6/15/1975&g=119&d=A .....

Good afternoon! Would anyone like tea? I've got this nice orange blossom-almond-vanilla white tea that is warming my hands, smells wonderful, and has just enough caffeine.
Enjoyed the puzzle. If the early week is upping its game, I'm all for it.
Always glad to see Knex. My kids loved them - I'm pretty sure I still have two crates of them in the attic. Yeah, along with all the Fisher Price, Legos, and stuffed animals. The books are all still on the regular shelves. I'm one of "those" moms.

I was doing this on my phone, minimised the app and did some work, went back to the puzzle to find the timer at 1 hour 30 min!!! Nobody told me it doesn't pause it automatically like on the web version... A minute's silence for my poor, poor average time...
Anyway, I loved the puzzle - I especially liked that you could use the theme to add in a few letters even if you didn't know the answer yet, knowing that the first 3 letters of each half will be the same. Some themes don't offer anything at all except an, "Oh, I see" after you finish.
Thanks Mr Aaronson!

Spent so time trying to figure out the veggie because I had ONADIET instead of ONAFAST and DARK instead of FUNK.

I mean, I've never heard of CUKE as a short form of cucumber but maybe it's another Americanism I need to add to my list. Otherwise a fun solve but waaaaaaaay over my average time.

TIL: 
CUKE (see above)
JAKE is an olde way of saying "OK"
Anyone get the bug on the app where you solve the puzzle and get the completion screen, then a few hours later it goes back to "you still have clues left to crack"?

Related to the constructors comments not the puzzle.

I traveled once by train in the late sixties and again in the early 90s.  I am surprised our constructor survived the hot dog.

Perhaps a listen to Mood Indigo.

Thank you Adam, fine Tuesday fare.
Kinda perfect for a Tuesday. Thanks Adam, well done.
Awaiting 2024 Super Mega puzzle winners list! Today was supposed to be the big reveal. Crickets. C‚Äômon NY Times. This is torture.
Slow finish for me, but altogether a fun puzzle! I QUITE enjoyed the number of Q‚Äôs. Thanks Adam!
Great puzzle but a bit of a misdirection for a Tuesday: lots of unexpectedly tough (but fun) clues.
Really nicely done, Adam. Thank you!

I got 6A immediately because I am a big fan of Troy & Abed In The Morning

Sometimes fake TV show bits in sitcoms are quite helpful!
"I was about to quibble with the cluing for 11D, but then I realized the 'U.S.' part of the disambiguation makes it true," said a 37-year resident of: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_(state)

Thanks for a nicely crunchy Tuesday puzzle, Adam. Certainly not a walk in the park, and I felt great when the penny dropped. 
In these scary times, I don‚Äôt know what I would do without my daily puzzles.
It's a fine puzzle, but not consistent with the typical level of difficulty offered by a Tuesday puzzle.
This was terrible

I think the puzzles while Will Shortz was on leave were easier on average than the ones before or since. This one took me beyond my average time but I don't mind. It's a really good puzzle. I especially enjoyed the Q's, the X's, and the V's.

For some reason when I got to U_ER for "____ fees," UBER was the only answer I could consider. I spent way too long trying to figure out which letter was off in "BOXEBIN" for "Pens." I should have guessed that I needed an S to make it a verb!

Other than that, this was a fairly smooth solve for me, and a fun one.
I loved this puzzle. Not too difficult, with a very clever theme!
Mail(male) man. My husband likes to make it non-gendered and says ‚Äúperson person‚Äù. :)
Some people do puzzles on a train, others create them.  Kudos to Adam on crafting a fun and challenging puzzle.
Way too hard for a Tuesday! Knex? Niqab? More like a Thursday puzzle.

Oh man, this puzzle took me forever. I can't say  I mind a challenge, but the difficulty level was a  bit much for a Tuesday. Ease us into our week guys! I was stuck on the SW corner for a long time, but the breakthrough happened and, it's fine, I got 'er done!

While I can understand where the difficulty comments stem from, I thought the theme of this puzzle made it easy enough for a Tuesday. It allowed for many blanks to be filled even if you didn't have the full answer nor the cross through a little logic. I.e. _ _ _ _ _ E_IST easily fills to E_ITSE_IST.
Lovely! Props for all the xs and qs, does anybody track the scrabble value of NYT solves?

Off-topic to today's puzzle (I leave the Monday and Tuesday puzzles for my wife and daughter): What determines when a comment section closes? The other day I did a puzzle (a Sunday) from April 2, 2023, and the comment section is still open - but the comment section for this past Sunday, February 2, 2025, which I just completed (and liked) is already closed. So how come? And why close the comment section on any puzzle unless it's turned into a saloon brawl?

what an absolutely delightful puzzle. i even laughed out loud a few times, because of some especially clever cluing. this felt extra fun and chewy for a tuesday.
thanks, adam aaronson!

ü§© Genius! Delightful! Thank you for this fun puzzle. The BACKFLIPS theme appealed to my love of puns and word play. Also IRA, MAILMAN.  It did take me longer than usual but in the end so satisfying. I was really stumped by the hijab, but love learning new terms.
Thanks again because this world be cray
This was a good Thursday puzzle!  The lack of difficulty quality control continues....
Way too hard for a Tues.

@Dave S 

The crunchy heel of a Polish sourdough loaf is one of the simplest and tastiest of my culinary treats.

@Dave S 

Actually, cornbread or corn muffins are much better for chunking in chili, but bread can be a good substitute if you're out of those.
@Dave My mother used to send me down to the local bakery in the morning for a loaf of Rye sliced with seeds.  The ENDS never made it home.
@Dave S I actually love the ends! Funny but I do!

@Andrzej 

It will be difficult to ‚Äúdissolve‚Äù the EPA, at least immediately. After the Cuyahoga River caught fire in the late 60s, Nixon had to do something politically, so he created the EPA to consolidate all of the actions (often ineffective) of various agencies trying to stem the poisoning of our air, water, and land. Since then, Congress has passed many laws requiring the EPA to enforce them, making it a regulator as well an analyst and advisor.

Since Reagan, the red team has been trying to wrest control away from Congress, centralize it back under the President, and diminish its powers to regulate businesses. For example, back in the 80s, Reagan appointed Anne (Gorsuch) Burford to be its administrator. She slashed the budget and workforce and was credibly accused of intentionally preventing the enforcement of regulations and withholding pollution funds to influence a political campaign. She ended up resigning in disgrace. Her 15 year old son, Neil, reportedly was angry that she resigned and told her she did nothing wrong since she only did what ‚Äúthe President ordered.‚Äù Neil went on to become one of the right wing Supreme Court justices of the tainted Robert‚Äôs court that recently ruled that the President was above the law when acting in his/her official capacity.

So this isn‚Äôt just Trump. It‚Äôs been going on for 45 years. Four and one half decades over which we could have been gradually and efficiently de-carbonizing our economy.  Instead, we continue to do‚Ä¶this.

@Oikofuge 

I thought of all the solvers outside of the United States as soon as I saw "Crimson Tide" as a clue.

The University of Alabama got that nickname for their football team (the type of football where you throw the ball, of course) in 1907 when a sports writer described the team as victoriously sweeping across the field "like a crimson tide."

They had (and still have) red jerseys. I've seen the phrase attributed to red mud covering the players, but that seems doubtful. It has nothing to do with algal blooms, though.

@Bruce 
Thanks for that explanation, I saw BAMA and thought ‚Äòwhat has that got to do with the ex-president? Duh. Should have known it was a sports ref. I have come across the term crimson tide in other puzzles, but couldn‚Äôt recall what it stood for.

@Oikofuge
The funny thing is, I‚Äôm pretty sure that 99% of Americans who don‚Äôt speak Japanese pronounce it to rhyme with ‚Äúkey,‚Äù regardless of how it‚Äôs spelled. Another thing of note is that, in Japanese, the word SAKE on its own usually just means an alcoholic beverage in general. While I‚Äôm sure any waiter or bartender who‚Äôs ever served tourists would know what you meant, saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôll have a sake, please‚Äù is roughly equivalent to saying ‚ÄúI‚Äôll have a brewed or distilled spirit, or perhaps a cocktail, please.‚Äù The most common term for the brewed rice-based drink is ‚Äúnihonshu‚Äù (though, as I mentioned in a reply to another comment, what this clue describes specifically would be called ‚Äúkanzake‚Äù).
